Main point would come down to autonomy & control, ironically. A financial derivative of # bitcoin is no longer a digital bearer instrument
11/ Only closing thought is derivs are somewhat a bastardization of the beauty of # bitcoin, but a necessary one 4 institutions to get comfy
10/ So, in short, congrats to # LedgerX for a win that is bigger than the company, and good for # bitcoin at large http://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/pr7592-17 …
9/ Risk management: big institutions get nervous w/ naked exposure to # bitcoin. Derivatives allow flexibility in duration and type of risk
8/ ..lead the charge in building institutional liquidity. As they play w/ # bitcoin derivs, they will inevitably play directly w/ $ BTC too
6/ Liquidity: derivatives can be more liquid than the underlying. For institutions wanting to put billions to work, this is vital 4 # bitcoin
5/ The risk is one that risk committees know how to analyze, and will likely allow them to get comfortable w/ # bitcoin exposure more quickly
4/ Counterparty risk then becomes reliant on financial stability of derivative issuer. While this is a bit backwards from # bitcoin's ethos..
3/ For a number of derivatives they don't need to be backed by the underlying asset. This means there is no underlying # bitcoin to be hacked
2/ Counterparties: many institutions struggle w/ the idea of # bitcoin custody. With derivatives, the counterparty is a *less foreign* beast
1/ # bitcoin derivatives to institutional adoption for 3 main reasons: 1) counterparties 2) liquidity 3) risk mgmt http://www.cftc.gov/PressRoom/PressReleases/pr7592-17 …
